Federal Court
Rennie, J.
April 25, 2013.
Counsel:
Casimir Eziefule, for the applicant;
Jocelyn Espejo Clark, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Casimir Eziefule, Windsor, Ontario, for the applicant;
William F. Pentney, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Toronto, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1]
Rennie, J.
: The applicant applied for permanent residence in Canada under the Federal Skilled Worker (FSW) class on the basis of his stated experience under national occupational classification code (NOC) 7372, driller and blaster. He has a bachelor's degree in geology and a certificate in blasting from the Ministry of Mines and Steel Development in Nigeria. He is employed as a quarry supervisor in Nigeria.

[2]
Subsection 75(2) of the
Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
, SOR/2002-227 (
Regulations
) describes a skilled worker as,
inter alia
, a foreign national who has performed the tasks described in the lead statement for the occupation as set out in the NOC occupational descriptions and performed a substantial number of the main duties of the occupation, including all "essential" duties.

[3]
A Citizenship and Immigration Canada agent determined that the applicant did not provide evidence that he satisfied this requirement and was not eligible for further processing pursuant to subsection 75(3) of the
Regulations
.

[4]
The decision is a form letter which states that the agent was not satisfied that the applicant had performed the actions in the lead statement for the occupation or a substantial number of the main duties. The agent subsequently swore an affidavit for this judicial review stating that the applicant's evidence only demonstrated experience in two of the listed main duties.

[5]
Decision makers may not supplement their reasons by way of an affidavit, but they may provide an explanation for their notes made contemporaneous to the decision:
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  paras 24-25.

[6]
In this case, the agent has no contemporaneous notes which describe her reasoning process. The affidavit was sworn on July 30, 2012, three months after the decision, casting doubt as to its reliability. It necessarily goes beyond explaining the agent's notes, as there are none, and is tendered as reasons for the decision. The affidavit is therefore inadmissible.

[7]
The applicant's employer provided a letter stating that, among other things, he: (a) schedules, supervises and coordinates drilling operations, (b) maps the pattern of holes and determines their size and spacing, (c) decides when to suspend or continue drilling, (d) calculates the amount of explosives required, (e) supervises subordinates in carrying out charging operations, (g) ensures safety precautions are followed, and (h) connects the blasting circuit.

[8]
The NOC occupational description states that, "Blasters in this group fill blast holes with explosives and detonate explosives." There are six main duties listed, several of which could arguably correspond with the tasks described in the applicant's evidence, particularly (b) (e) (g) and (h) noted above. It is not for this Court to determine whether the applicant has in fact performed the actions described in the lead statement and a substantial number of the main duties. The agent must do so, with some line of reasoning which provides a basis for review. As Justice Richard Mosley found in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  it is impossible to assess the reasonableness of the officer's conclusions without knowing which duties had not been performed.

[9]
The decision provides no insight into the agent's reasoning process. The agent merely stated her conclusion, without explanation. It is entirely unclear why the decision was reached.

[10]
Newfoundland and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  does not save the decision.
Newfoundland Nurses
ensures that the focus of judicial review remains on the outcome or decision itself, and not the process by which that outcome was reached. Where readily apparent, evidentiary
lacunae
may be filled in when supported by the evidence, and logical inferences, implicit to the result but not expressly drawn. A reviewing court looks to the record with a view to upholding the decision.

[11]
Newfoundland Nurses
is not an open invitation to the Court to provide reasons that were not given, nor is it licence to guess what findings might have been made or to speculate as to what the tribunal might have been thinking. This is particularly so where the reasons are silent on a critical issue. It is ironic that
Newfoundland Nurses
, a case which at its core is about deference and standard of review, is urged as authority for the supervisory court to do the task that the decision maker did not do, to supply the reasons that might have been given and make findings of fact that were not made. This is to turn the jurisprudence on its head.
Newfoundland Nurses
allows reviewing courts to connect the dots on the page where the lines, and the direction they are headed, may be readily drawn. Here, there were no dots on the page.
JUDGMENT

[12]
THIS COURT'S JUDGMENT is that
the application for judicial review is granted. The agent's decision is set aside, and the matter is referred back to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for reconsideration by a different agent. There is no question for certification.
.........................
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> applicant submitted an application for permanent residency under the Federal Skilled Worker category, based on his reported experience as a driller and blaster, National Occupational Classification (NOC) code 7372. He holds a bachelor's degree in geology and a certificate in blasting from the Ministry of Mines and Steel Development, Nigeria. He works as a career supervisor in Nigeria. [2]
Subsection 75(2) of
Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
, SOR/2002-227 (the Regulations) describes the skilled worker, among other things, as the foreign national who has performed all of the tasks appearing in the main statement established for the profession in the occupational descriptions of the National Occupational Classification, and who has performed an appreciable part of the main functions of the profession, in particular all the essential functions. [3]
A Citizenship and Immigration Canada officer determined that the applicant had not provided proof that he met these requirements and that his application could not be processed further, in accordance with subsection 75(3) of the Regulations. [4]
The decision is a standard letter indicating that the officer was not satisfied that the applicant had performed the tasks set out in the primary statement established for the profession or performed an appreciable portion of the primary functions of the profession. The agent subsequently swore, for the purposes of this judicial review, an affidavit in which she declared that the evidence presented by the applicant established that he had already performed only two of the main functions of the profession. [5]
Decision-makers cannot supplement their reasons with an affidavit, but they can explain the notes taken at the time of the decision:
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> and 25. [6]
In this case, the officer did not take notes to describe her reasoning. The affidavit was sworn on July 30, 2012, three months after the decision, calling into question its reliability. Obviously, the affidavit does not amount to a simple explanation of the officer's notes, since there are no notes; rather, it serves as the reasons for the decision. It is therefore inadmissible. [7]
The applicant's employer provided a letter which states, among other things, that the applicant: (a) plans, supervises and coordinates drilling operations, (b) maps holes and determines their diameter and spacing, (c) decides when to suspend or continue drilling, (d) calculates the quantity of explosives required, (e) supervises subordinates who carry out loading operations, (g) ensures that safety measures are applied, and (h) connects the blast circuit. [8]
According to the NOC occupational description, blasters in this group load explosives into blast holes and detonate charges. Six main functions are listed, several of which could correspond to the tasks described in the plaintiff's evidence, in particular tasks (b), (e), (g) and (h) noted above. It is not for the Court to determine whether the applicant has in fact performed the tasks set out in the main statement and an appreciable part of the main functions. It is up to the officer to do so and explain their reasoning, which may give rise to judicial review. As Justice Richard Mosley ruled in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> it is impossible to assess the reasonableness of the officer's conclusions without knowing which duties were not performed. [9]
The decision sheds no light on the officer's reasoning. The agent simply stated her conclusion, without explaining it. It is impossible to know how she arrived at this decision. [10]
The stop
Newfoundland and <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , does not validate the decision. The stop
Newfoundland Nurses
establishes that judicial review concerns the decision itself, not the decision-making process. Where evident, gaps in the evidence may be filled if it is possible to do so on the basis of evidence and logical inferences, virtually included in the result, but not expressly drawn. The reviewing court examines the file with the aim of confirming the decision. [11]
The stop
Newfoundland Nurses
does not give the Court full latitude to provide reasons which have not been given, nor does it authorize it to guess what conclusions might have been reached or to speculate on what the court may have thought. This is particularly the case when the reasons ignore an essential issue. It is ironic that the ruling
Newfoundland Nurses
, a case that is essentially about deference and standard of review, be invoked as the precedent that would direct the court with supervisory power to do the work omitted by the decision maker, to provide the reasons that could have been given, and to make the findings of fact that were not made. This is applying case law in reverse. The stop
Newfoundland Nurses
allows control lessons to connect the dots on the page when the lines, and the direction they take, can be easily discerned. Here, there aren't even any dots on the page.
JUDGMENT [12]
THE COURT RULES that
the application for judicial review is granted. The officer's decision is set aside, and the matter is referred back to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for further consideration by another officer. There are no questions to be certified.
[End of document]

Il est titulaire d'un baccalauréat en géologie et d'un certificat en dynamitage délivré par le ministère des Mines et du Développement de l'acier du Nigeria. Il travaille comme superviseur de carrière au Nigeria.
[2]
Le paragraphe 75(2) du
Règlement sur l'immigration et la protection des réfugiés
, DORS/2002-227 (le Règlement) décrit le travailleur qualifié entre autres comme l'étranger qui a accompli l'ensemble des tâches figurant dans l'énoncé principal établi pour la profession dans les descriptions des professions de la Classification nationale des professions, et qui a exercé une partie appréciable des fonctions principales de la profession, notamment toutes les fonctions  essentielles .
[3]
Une agente de Citoyenneté et Immigration Canada a déterminé que le demandeur n'avait pas fourni de preuve établissant qu'il satisfaisait à ces exigences et que sa demande ne pouvait être traitée plus avant, conformément au paragraphe 75(3) du Règlement.
[4]
La décision est une lettre type indiquant que l'agente n'était pas convaincue que le demandeur avait accompli les tâches figurant dans l'énoncé principal établi pour la profession ou exercé une partie appréciable des fonctions principales de la profession. L'agente a par la suite souscrit, aux fins du présent contrôle judiciaire, un affidavit dans lequel elle déclare que la preuve présentée par le demandeur établissait que celui-ci avait déjà accompli seulement deux des fonctions principales de la profession.
[5]

 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> et 25.
[6]
En l'espèce, l'agente n'a pas pris de notes pour décrire son raisonnement. L'affidavit a été souscrit le 30 juillet 2012, trois mois après la décision, ce qui remet en question sa fiabilité. Évidemment, l'affidavit ne se résume pas à une simple explication des notes de l'agente, puisqu'il n'y a pas de notes; il sert plutôt de motifs de la décision. Il est donc irrecevable.
[7]
L'employeur du demandeur a fourni une lettre dans laquelle il est dit, entre autres, que le demandeur: a) planifie, supervise et coordonne des opérations de forage, b) dresse la carte des trous et détermine leur diamètre et leur espacement, c) décide quand suspendre ou poursuivre le forage, d) calcule la quantité d'explosifs requis, e) supervise les subordonnés qui exécutent des opérations de chargement, g) veille à l'application des mesures de sécurité, et h) raccorde le circuit de tir.
[8]
Selon la description de la profession énoncée dans la CNP,  [l] es dynamiteurs de ce groupe chargent des explosifs dans des trous de dynamitage et font exploser des charges . Six fonctions principales sont énumérées, dont plusieurs pourraient correspondre aux tâches décrites dans la preuve du demandeur, en particulier les tâches b), e), g) et h) indiquées ci-dessus. Il ne revient pas à la Cour de déterminer si le demandeur a bel et bien accompli les tâches figurant dans l'énoncé principal et une partie appréciable des fonctions principales. Il incombe à l'agent de le faire et d'expliquer son raisonnement, qui peut donner ouverture à contrôle judiciaire. Comme le juge Richard Mosley a statué dans
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  il est impossible d'évaluer le caractère raisonnable des conclusions de l'agent sans savoir quelles fonctions n'ont pas été exercées.
[9]
La décision ne jette aucune lumière sur le raisonnement de l'agente. L'agente s'est contentée d'énoncer sa conclusion, sans l'expliquer. Il est impossible de savoir comment elle est parvenue à cette décision.
[10]
L'arrêt
Newfoundland and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , ne valide pas la décision. L'arrêt
Newfoundland Nurses
établit que le contrôle judiciaire porte sur la décision en soi, et non sur le processus décisionnel. Lorsqu'elles sont manifestes, les lacunes de la preuve peuvent être comblées s'il est possible de le faire en s'appuyant sur la preuve et sur des inférences logiques, virtuellement comprises dans le résultat, mais non expressément tirées. La cour de révision examine le dossier dans le but de confirmer la décision.
[11]
L'arrêt
Newfoundland Nurses
ne donne pas à la Cour toute la latitude voulue pour fournir des motifs qui n'ont pas été donnés, ni ne l'autorise à deviner quelles conclusions auraient pu être tirées ou à émettre des hypothèses sur ce que le tribunal a pu penser. C'est particulièrement le cas quand les motifs passent sous silence une question essentielle. Il est ironique que l'arrêt
Newfoundland Nurses
, une affaire qui concerne essentiellement la déférence et la norme de contrôle, soit invoqué comme le précédent qui commanderait au tribunal ayant le pouvoir de surveillance de faire le travail omis par le décideur, de fournir les motifs qui auraient pu être donnés et de formuler les conclusions de fait qui n'ont pas été tirées. C'est appliquer la jurisprudence à l'envers. L'arrêt
Newfoundland Nurses
permet aux cours de contrôle de relier les points sur la page quand les lignes, et la direction qu'elles prennent, peuvent être facilement discernées. Ici, il n'y a même pas de points sur la page.
JUGEMENT
[12]
LA COUR STATUE que
la demande de contrôle judiciaire est accueillie. La décision de l'agent est annulée, et l'affaire est renvoyée à Citoyenneté et Immigration Canada pour nouvel examen par un autre agent. Il n'y a pas de question à certifier.
[End of document]

the application for judicial review is granted. The officer's decision is set aside, and the matter is referred back to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for further consideration by another officer. There are no questions to be certified.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227 ( Regulations )
subsection 75(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations , SOR/2002-227
legal_issues: The admissibility of supplementary evidence submitted via affidavit to support a prior administrative decision.
The sufficiency of reasoning provided in support of an administrative decision.
The standard of review applicable to administrative decisions, particularly concerning the extent to which a reviewing court can infer unstated reasoning.
The requirements for demonstrating eligibility under a skilled worker immigration program, specifically regarding the performance of essential job duties.
The procedural requirements for administrative reconsideration of a decision.
factual_background: An individual applied for permanent residency in Canada under the Federal Skilled Worker class.
The application was based on the applicant’s experience as a driller and blaster (NOC 7372).
The applicant possesses a bachelor’s degree in geology and a blasting certificate from a Nigerian institution.
The applicant is employed as a quarry supervisor in Nigeria.
A Citizenship and Immigration Canada agent determined the applicant did not provide sufficient evidence to meet the requirements for the skilled worker class.
The agent’s decision was communicated via a standard letter lacking detailed reasoning.
Subsequently, the agent submitted an affidavit stating the applicant’s evidence demonstrated experience in only two of the occupation’s main duties.
The applicant’s employer provided a letter detailing the applicant’s responsibilities, including supervising drilling operations, calculating explosives, and ensuring safety.
The National Occupational Classification for blasters lists six main duties.
The agent did not create contemporaneous notes regarding the reasoning behind the decision.

Applicants: Applicant meets the requirements of subsection 75(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations as a skilled worker under NOC 7372 (driller and blaster).
Applicant possesses a bachelor's degree in geology and a blasting certificate from Nigeria.

Applicant’s employer letter demonstrates experience performing duties corresponding to the NOC 7372 description, including scheduling/supervising drilling, mapping holes, calculating explosives, supervising charging, ensuring safety, and connecting blasting circuits.
The agent’s decision lacked reasoning and explanation, failing to identify which duties were not performed.
The agent’s affidavit submitted for judicial review was inadmissible as it was created three months after the initial decision and served as new reasons, rather than an explanation of existing notes.
The decision should be set aside and reconsidered by a different agent.
Respondents: Applicant did not provide evidence satisfying the requirements of subsection 75(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations.
Applicant did not perform the tasks described in the lead statement for the occupation of driller and blaster (NOC 7372) or a substantial number of the main duties.
The agent’s initial decision was based on a lack of sufficient evidence of the applicant’s experience.
The agent’s affidavit was permissible to clarify the basis of the decision.
The principles in *Newfoundland Nurses* allow for filling evidentiary gaps with logical inferences and upholding the decision.

court_analysis: The court found the agent's decision to deny the applicant's permanent residency application invalid due to a lack of reasoned explanation. The agent simply stated a conclusion without detailing *why* the applicant did not meet the requirements of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations.

The court deemed the agent's subsequent affidavit inadmissible as evidence of the reasoning behind the decision. The affidavit was created three months after the initial decision and, crucially, lacked any contemporaneous notes to support it; it essentially *replaced* reasons rather than explaining them, violating established legal principles regarding supplementing reasons with affidavits.

The court acknowledged that the applicant's employer's letter provided evidence of duties that arguably aligned with the NOC description for a driller and blaster. However, it emphasized that *determining whether these duties met the regulatory requirements was the agent's responsibility*, not the court's.

The court rejected the argument that the principle established in *Newfoundland Nurses* allowed it to fill gaps in the agent's reasoning. It clarified that *Newfoundland Nurses* permits connecting readily apparent dots, but does not authorize the court to create reasons where none exist or to speculate on the agent's thought process, especially concerning a critical issue like which duties were not performed.

The court applied the principle that a reviewing court must be able to assess the reasonableness of a decision, which requires understanding the basis for that decision. The complete absence of reasoning in the agent's decision made it impossible to conduct a meaningful review, leading to the granting of judicial review and referral of the case back to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for reconsideration by a different agent.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is granted.
The agent's decision is set aside.
The matter is referred back to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for reconsideration by a different agent.
There is no question for certification.
